DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text to describe the anatomic location of metastatic disease.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: (MET-uh-STAT-ik) Having to do with metastasis, which is the spread of cancer from one part of the body to another._A definite pathologic process with a characteristic set of signs and symptoms. It may affect the whole body or any of its parts, and its etiology, pathology, and prognosis may be known or unknown._Relating to anatomy._A position, site, or point in space where something can be found.

Concepts.definition: A term referring to the clinical or pathologic observation of a tumor extension from its original site of growth to another anatomic site.

Any abnormal condition of the body or mind that causes discomfort, dysfunction, or distress to the person affected or those in contact with the person. The term is often used broadly to include injuries, disabilities, syndromes, symptoms, deviant behaviors, and atypical variations of structure and function.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Having no previous example or precedent or parallel; of a kind not seen before._A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation.  Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia.  Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias._Something that happens at a given place and time._Named locations of or within the body._Text; the words of something written.

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: New Neoplasm Event Anatomic Site Text
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: New; having no previous example or precedent or parallel.:A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.:Event; something that happens at a given place and time.:Named locations of, or within, the body.:Text; the words of something written.

Concepts.definition: Having no previous example or precedent or parallel; of a kind not seen before.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.
Something that happens at a given place and time.
Named locations of or within the body.
